questions.text: Which of the following vaccines should not be given to a child with severe combined immunodeficiency disorder (SCID)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MMR is contraindicated in a child with SCID.

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) indicates a markedly weakened immune system, so live attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in these children. Live vaccines can replicate in the host and may cause serious infection when immune defenses are impaired.

General situations where live vaccines should not be administered include:

  • Primary immunodeficiency disorders
  • Conditions with significant immune suppression, such as:
    • Leukemia or lymphoma
    • Other malignancies
    • Ongoing corticosteroid therapy
    • Treatment with alkylating agents or antimetabolites
    • Therapeutic radiation
  • Pregnancy, because of potential harm to the fetus

Explanations for other Options:

IPV (Option A): IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine) Contains killed poliovirus, not live virus. It is Safe and recommended even in severe immunodeficiency.

Hepatitis B vaccine (Option B): A recombinant sub-unit vaccine that uses only the hepatitis B surface antigen. It Cannot cause infection and is safe for immunocompromised children.

DTaP (Option D): It Includes inactivated toxoids (diphtheria, tetanus) and acellular pertussis components. It is Entirely non-live, so it is safe to administer in SCID.

choices.text: Reassure the parents as this much variation is common
Get a development test done immediately
Get an MRI of the brain

questions.text: A 9 month-old child cannot sit without support. The baby can roll and say mama & dada. The child is generally clingy and has stranger anxiety. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The appropriate next step in managing this child's development is reassurance, since it is a normal developmental variant. Sitting without support typically emerges around 8 months of age, but the upper normal limit is about 10 months. Since this child is 9 months old, the ability to sit independently is still within the expected developmental window, and no intervention is needed beyond reassurance.

Upper limit of age for the attainment of milestones

Explanations for other Options:

Get a development test done immediately (Option B): Not required because all other milestones are age-appropriate and the delay is still within the normal range.

Refer to higher centre (Option C): Referral is unnecessary unless multiple milestones are delayed or there are red flags such as loss of skills or abnormal tone.

Get an MRI of the brain (Option D): Neuroimaging is indicated only when there are signs of neurological disease (e.g., seizures, abnormal head size, regression), which are absent here.

Key takeaway:

Fine motor milestones:

questions.text: A newborn delivered at 36 weeks has breathing difficulty which improved with Fi02 30%. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 36-week newborn with mild respiratory distress needing only 30 % FiO2 and a chest X-ray showing fluid within the interlobar fissures is most consistent with Transient Tachypnea of the Newborn (TTN).

TTN occurs more often in term or late-preterm infants and is linked to factors such as twin pregnancy, maternal asthma or hypertension, cesarean delivery without labour, precipitous birth, gestational diabetes, fetal macrosomia, and perinatal depression.

The disorder results from incomplete absorption of fetal lung fluid, which lowers lung compliance and hampers gas exchange.

Typical features include rapid breathing soon after birth (rate >60/min) sometimes with mild retractions or expiratory grunting, and any cyanosis usually resolves with low-flow oxygen (<40 %).

Chest imaging commonly reveals prominent perihilar streaking and fluid within the interlobar fissures, with occasional small pleural effusions.

Management is supportive, and most infants improve quickly without long-term problems.

Explanations for other Options:

Hyaline membrane disease (Option A): Usually affects very premature infants (<34 weeks) and causes severe respiratory distress with a reticulogranular "ground-glass" chest X-ray and air bronchograms, not a brief oxygen requirement.

Meconium aspiration syndrome (Option C): Seen mainly in term or post-term babies with meconium-stained amniotic fluid and shows patchy coarse infiltrates and areas of hyperinflation on X-ray, unlike this case.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with intense itching, especially at night. On examination, there are multiple excoriated papules and burrows seen over the palms, soles, and trunk. A clinical diagnosis of scabies is made. Which of the following drugs are appropriate and safe for use in infants with scabies?
1. Permethrin 5% cream
2. Benzyl benzoate 25% lotion
3. Crotamiton 10% cream
4. Ivermectin
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Permethrin 5% and Crotamiton 10% are used to treat scabies in infants.

Permethrin 5% cream is the preferred first-line therapy for scabies.It is applied over the entire body twice, one week apart, and can be safely used in infants older than 2 months.

Crotamiton 10% ointment is another option, applied overnight on days 1, 2, 3, and again on day 8.

In contrast, ivermectin should not be given to children weighing less than 15 kg, and benzyl benzoate 25% lotion is not recommended for pediatric patients.

questions.text: A child has non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting, around 3 weeks after birth. Abdominal examination was normal but the child has poor weight gain along with feed intolerance. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A six-week-old infant with poor weight gain, feeding difficulty, and non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting immediately after feeds-while having normal bowel movements and an unremarkable abdominal exam-most likely has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

GERD is the backward flow of stomach contents through the lower esophageal sphincter into the esophagus. It is the most common esophageal disorder in childhood and may occur as a normal physiologic process in infants.

Typical presentation includes effortless post-meal regurgitation. When reflux causes esophagitis, the infant can show irritability, back-arching, choking, gagging, or refusal to feed, leading to failure to thrive. Some babies also develop airway symptoms such as stridor, obstructive apnea, or lower respiratory issues when reflux aggravates underlying airway conditions like laryngomalacia or bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

Most infants outgrow reflux spontaneously by 12-24 months. Management depends on age and symptom severity: avoid overfeeding, burp the infant well during and after feeds, and consider thickened feeds to both increase caloric density and lessen visible regurgitation.

Explanations for other Options:

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS)(Option A): Typically causes forceful, projectile non-bilious vomiting beginning at 3–6 weeks of age and often reveals an olive-shaped mass or visible gastric peristalsis on abdominal exam, findings absent in this child.

Cow milk protein allergy (Option C):More often presents with blood-streaked stools, diarrhea, eczema, or vomiting that may be bilious or accompanied by other allergic symptoms, not isolated effortless regurgitation with normal abdominal findings.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D):Generally produces bilious vomiting (if distal to the duodenum) or marked abdominal distension and abnormal bowel sounds, which are not seen here.

questions.text: A child presented with petechiae, purpura and platelet count of 10,000. Bone marrow aspirate shows increased megakaryocytes. What is the treatment to be given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

First-line treatment for severe thrombocytopenia with bleeding or very low counts is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or high-dose corticosteroids to rapidly raise the platelet count.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is the most likely diagnosis in a child with petechiae, purpura, severe thrombocytopenia (platelets ~10,000/µL), and bone marrow showing increased megakaryocytes, which indicates peripheral platelet destruction rather than marrow failure.

Explanations for other Options:

Bone marrow transplant (BMT)(Option A): Reserved for marrow failure syndromes (e.g., aplastic anemia, leukemia) or certain congenital disorders, not for typical ITP where the marrow is functioning.

Methotrexate (MTX) (Option B): An antimetabolite used in cancer therapy and some autoimmune diseases; it has no role in the acute management of ITP.

Aspirin (Option D):It is Contraindicated because it inhibits platelet function and would worsen bleeding risk.

choices.text: Loss of protein and presence of edema
Calorie deficit with normal serum protein

questions.text: Out of the following, which represents marasmus accurately?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Severe calorie deficit with normal serum protein describes the metabolic status of Marasmus.

Marasmus represents a state of severe calorie deficiency with normal or near-normal serum proteins.

It results from prolonged starvation or chronic illness in which both fat stores and muscle tissue are broken down for energy, causing extreme wasting. The somatic protein compartment (skeletal muscle) is catabolized to supply amino acids, while the visceral protein compartment (including serum albumin) remains largely preserved, so serum albumin levels are usually normal or only mildly reduced.

Clinically, the child is extremely thin with pronounced loss of subcutaneous fat. Muscles of the shoulders, arms, thighs, and buttocks are markedly wasted. Loss of the buccal fat pad produces an aged or "monkey-like" facies, and the lax skin of the buttocks gives a "baggy pants" look. Despite the profound emaciation, there is no edema, and the child often appears relatively alert and responsive.

Explanations for other Options:

Loss of protein and presence of edema(Option A): This describes kwashiorkor, not marasmus. Kwashiorkor results from inadequate protein intake with relative calorie sufficiency, leading to hypoalbuminemia and pitting edema.

Low cortisol (Option C): Children with marasmus generally maintain normal or even elevated cortisol levels as a stress response; low cortisol is not characteristic of this condition.

Increased insulin (Option D): Severe calorie deprivation causes low insulin and increased counter-regulatory hormones (like cortisol and glucagon) to promote catabolism, so high insulin is inconsistent with marasmus.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, and a cherry red spot on fundoscopic examination. The startle reflex is normal. Enzyme assay reveals a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A deficiency of sphingomyelinase leads to Niemann-Pick disease type A, a lysosomal storage disorder. It causes accumulation of sphingomyelin in macrophages and other tissues, resulting in hepatosplenomegaly. The cherry-red spot occurs due to storage in retinal ganglion cells, while the startle reflex remains normal initially. Neurological deterioration develops gradually, distinguishing it from other storage disorders like Tay-Sachs.

This inherited lysosomal storage disorder usually appears in early infancy. Although newborns are healthy at birth, they soon develop failure to thrive, progressive hepatosplenomegaly, and marked psychomotor delay. Over time, affected infants experience profound motor decline and intellectual deterioration, with death typically occurring by 2-3 years of age.

The disease results from absent or markedly reduced activity of acid sphingomyelinase, leading to accumulation of sphingomyelin within cells of the monocyte-macrophage system. Examination of bone marrow or lymph nodes often reveals lipid-laden foam cells, and the diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating low sphingomyelinase activity in peripheral leukocytes.

Management is largely supportive-such as physical therapy and assisted feeding-but olipudase alfa has recently been approved to treat non-neurological manifestations of the disorder.

conditions associated with a cherry-red spot on the retina include:

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal or cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage disorders, such as:
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (e.g., Tay-Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann-Pick disease
  • Drug or toxin exposure, for example from quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, or methanol.

Explanations for other Options:

Glucocerebrosidase (Option A): Gaucher disease results from glucocerebrosidase deficiency and is characterized by anemia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and skeletal involvement such as bone pain or fractures. Bone marrow examination reveals lipid-laden macrophages with a classic "crumpled tissue paper" cytoplasm.

Hexosaminidase A (Option C): A deficiency of Hexosaminidase A causes Tay-Sachs disease, which also leads to progressive neurodegeneration and a macular cherry-red spot. However, unlike Niemann-Pick disease, there is no hepatosplenomegaly, and lysosomes show a distinctive "onion-skin" appearance. An exaggerated startle response is typical.

Arylsulfatase A (Option D): Metachromatic leukodystrophy, due to arylsulfatase A deficiency, causes progressive demyelination and behavioral or cognitive decline. It does not produce hepatomegaly or a cherry-red macula.

Key takeaway:

Lipid storage Diseases:

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is seen in Tetralogy of Fallot.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart disease defined by four classic defects:

  • Severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Overriding aorta that receives blood from both ventricles
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Blood from the right ventricle passes through the obstructed pulmonary valve into the pulmonary artery, producing an ejection systolic murmur. Interestingly, the murmur's intensity is inversely proportional to the severity of pulmonary stenosis-more severe obstruction leads to a larger right-to-left shunt and increased cyanosis.

Clinical presentation includes dyspnea on exertion, exercise intolerance, and cyanotic spells (tet spells). These episodes often occur after waking or with exertion, during which the child may cry, become short of breath, lose consciousness, or experience seizures. Children often squat during these spells, which increases venous return and systemic vascular resistance, thereby improving pulmonary blood flow.

Examination findings:

  • Auscultation reveals a loud first heart sound, single second heart sound, and an ejection systolic murmur that ends before the single second sound.
  • ECG shows right axis deviation, right ventricular hypertrophy, T-wave inversion in right precordial leads, and occasionally P pulmonale.
  • Chest X-ray demonstrates a boot-shaped heart (coeur en sabot) due to absent main pulmonary artery segment and oligemic pulmonary fields.

Diagnosis is confirmed using echocardiography, which visualizes the VSD, right ventricular outflow obstruction, and aortic override.


Explanations for other Options:

Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) (Option A): TOF causes right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) due to obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract, not LVH.

Inter atrial septal defect (Option C): TOF involves a ventricular septal defect (VSD); the atrial septum is typically normal.

Transposition of great vessels (Option D): This is a separate congenital heart defect in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, and is not part of the TOF anatomy.

Key takeaway:

choices.text: Difficulty in excretion of conjugated bilirubin

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the mechanism of breast milk jaundice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breast milk jaundice typically presents as unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in otherwise healthy, term infants, appearing after the first week of life (late onset).The condition is thought to be caused by beta-glucuronidase in breast milk, which deconjugates bilirubin in the intestine, increasing enterohepatic circulation and slowing bilirubin excretion.

Explanations for other Options:

Late onset (Option B): Breast-milk jaundice does usually present after day 5-7, so it can be described as "later" than physiologic jaundice. However, the mechanism, specifically involves unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not just timing.

Beta glucronidase enzyme involved (Option C): β-glucuronidase in breast milk indeed contributes by deconjugating bilirubin in the gut, but the primary mechanism is still the resulting unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This is a contributing enzyme rather than the core biochemical abnormality.

Difficulty in excretion of conjugated bilirubin(Option D): This describes disorders with direct (conjugated) hyperbilirubinemia, such as biliary atresia or neonatal hepatitis, and is not the mechanism in breast-milk jaundice.

choices.text: Insulin mediated uptake of electrolytes, phosphate
Glucagon spike and cause more loss of phosphate and electrolyte

questions.text: A malnourished child, given too much food, developed hypophosphatemia & hypomagnesemia. What could be the mechanism of this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Insulin mediated uptake of electrolytes, phosphate is the mechanism responsible for the development of hypophosphatemia & hypomagnesemia in the child.This sudden intracellular shift leads to hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia-the hallmark of refeeding syndrome.

Refeeding syndrome is a serious metabolic complication seen when severely malnourished individuals are given nutrition too rapidly, including via total parenteral nutrition. The sudden carbohydrate intake triggers a surge in insulin, shifting the body from a catabolic to an anabolic state.

Elevated insulin stimulates glycogen and protein synthesis and activates the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, driving potassium into cells. Magnesium and phosphate also move intracellularly, leading to hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and marked hypophosphatemia-the key biochemical feature of this condition. Insulin additionally reduces renal phosphate reabsorption, worsening the deficit. Hyperglycemia may develop as the pancreas struggles to match the abrupt rise in blood glucose.

Risk factors include prolonged starvation, chronic alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obesity. If unrecognized, these electrolyte imbalances can cause life-threatening complications such as arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, respiratory failure, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, or death. Prevention relies on correcting fluid and electrolyte disturbances beforehand, giving thiamine, and advancing calorie intake slowly and carefully.

Explanations for other Options:

Catecholamine spike increases electrolyte uptake (Option A): Catecholamines may cause transient shifts of potassium but are not the primary trigger for the profound phosphate and magnesium drop seen in refeeding.

Urinary loss of phosphates (Option C): Renal wasting can lower phosphate, but in refeeding syndrome the major mechanism is intracellular shift, not kidney loss.

(Option D): Glucagon predominates during fasting, not during refeeding; it does not explain the post-feeding hypophosphatemia.
